rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation into the effects of participation in a co-operative as compared to a competitive task on intra-group attitudes of acceptance and rejection
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The present investigation attempts to study the age old problem of competition as compared to co-operation. Here is a present day, practical problem, much in the public eye and mind, much experimented upon, much discussed and very much more theorized about. However, in conformity with what has been said thus far, we wish to pursue this investigation in the manner of a personalistic analysis. We are not Interested, here, in the comparative efficiency of one method over the other as a general law applied to individuals. We are interested in the individual, in his happiness, his well- being, his future, his morale and how competition and co-operation affects him in these ways.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: PSYCHOLOGY -- MENTAL TESTS
SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY
Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The design and construction of a high voltage generator
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis is concerned with the design and construction of a high voltage generator capable of producing steady Potentials of approximately 100,000 volts. The generator is designed to be used principally for acceleration of ions or protons for use in nuclear reactions. Voltages of this nature may be used quite efficiently for producing low energy neutrons in a deuteron-deuterium reaction. Other reactions which are of interest in this r√§nge are the proton-lithium, protonboron and proton-fluorine reactions. (10). In addition to the above uses, the generator may be used in any apparatus which requires high DC potentials but does not draw more than a few hundred microamperes. The apparatus is of a semi-portable nature capable of being transported from one room to another like a laboratory tool. This portability is a radical departure from previous apparatus of this type. The circuit used is a form of the Cockcroft- Walton (6) or Greinacher (7) voltage multiplier.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The theory of elasticity of aeolotropic materials
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] In the present thesis a detailed review will be made of most of the work concerned with aeolotropic materials done by the above authors. The study is divided into six chapters. In the first chapter, the real variable method for the solution of two dimensional problems, as advanced by Green, is presented. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mathematics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The ideal in relation to the natural in the political philosophy of Plato / by William Goldberg
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Plato's Republic is essentially an ideal Republic. It is ideal in the sense that a rational polity would be in accord, when once established, with perfect knowledge and would resemble the divine pattern. Yet this abstract republic has its roots in two sources. It depends ultimately on a analysis of human nature and a conception of being. Thus in Plato natural and ideal factors are considered as being mutually interdependent, so far as the conception of the ideal Republic goes.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Political science
Plato -- Contributions in political science

rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Since the Interest behind this project was to elucidate the physiology of insulin secretion and the light such knowledge might shed on the pathogenesis of diabetes mellitus 5t is proposed to review in the historical section the more significant paoers pertinent to this subject. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Endocrinology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The molecular absorption spectrum of methyl alcohol in the 1.25 cm. region
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A double modulation system was used to detect molecular absorption lines in the 1.25 cm region. A pip, with a repetition rate of 55 kc, was used for the r.f. modulation in place of a sine wave, resulting in increased sensitivity. Thirty-four lines of methyl alcohol, twenty-five of which had not been reported previously, were measured. These were found to be equally spaced and were grouped into three series. Twenty-nine lines due to a mixture of methyl alcohol and water were measured. These were also equally spaced and were grouped into two series. The arguments in favour of attributing the spectra to pairs of molecules, joined by "hydrogen bonding", were advanced.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of several fertilizers and lime on the yield and botanical composition of a pasture sward on Sherbrooke sandy loam
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] An anonymous author (1923) wrote that: "Only the fact that grass will stand an almost incredible amount of abuse has prevented its utter destruction". Literature from all parte of the world shows the low production of most permanent grasslands. This low productivity is diversely attributed to lack of fertility, deficiency in management, and improper grazing practices. It is also seen that the yield and the vegetation of pastures can be materially and profitably improved by proper treatments.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics

rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It was the purpose of this experiment to attempt to reinforce the slab against shearing stresses in a practical and economical manner. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mechanical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A comparison of grain crops grown singly and in combination
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Trials involving the comparison of oats and barley grown singly with their mixtures in three different proportions were conducted in randomized blocks at six points in Quebec, during periods from two to five years. Percentages of each species in the crop, by weight, as well as their actual and expected yields were computed. Data show evidence of the complexity of phenomena involved in5 the competition between s-necies in mixture, brought about by such factors as varieties, proportions, stations and vears. Gains in one species were made usually at the other1s detriment. The barlev species has benefited generally from being grown in mixture. Mixtures have given yields intermediate between those of pure crops. However, some results indicate the possibility of yield increases with selected varieties in some districts. Notwithstanding the fact that growing barley and oat mixtures does not definitely increase yields, the practice is acceptable.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Renal function and experimental hypertension
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The work to be reported here was stimulated by the desire to study kidney function in the rat, particularly under the influence of various endocrine steroids. The experimental hypertension was thus produced, not by mechanical injury to the kidney, but hormonally. Most of the work has been performed in the last eighteen months, although its beginnings were in 1941.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effects of positive and negative incentives in serial learning : fixation and variability of response as a result of symbolic reward and symbolic punishment
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The questions to be answered by an examination of the results of these experiments are as follows: (1) Will an empirical baseline of repetition (as determined by control group results) be greater than that expected by chance? (2) Will the informative word "right" (symbolic reward) increase the number of repetitions to the item to which it is applied above an empirical baseline? (3) Will the informative word "wrong" (symbolic punishment) reduce the number of repetitions to the item to which it is applied below an empirical baseline.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: PSYCHOLOGY -- MENTAL TESTS
LEARNING, PSYCHOLOGY OF
Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Parasites of marine fishes of the Bay of Chaleur area
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The parasitic fauna of marine fish in eastern Canadian waters has not been studied up to date to any great extent. It was therefore decided to undertake a survey of the ecto- and endoparasites of codfish (Gadus callarias L.) and any other marine or migratory fish available at Grande- Riviere, County of Gaspe South, P.Q. This work was done from June to September 1947.There is no doubt that a heavy parasitic infestation causes disease in many cases although a marked tolerance is frequently shown. Furthermore, out of purely esthetic considerations, the economic value of a food fish is decreased when helminths are present. It would therefore be desirable to evolve adequate control measures.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Parasitology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Synthesis and polymerization of some substituted butadienes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Early in the polymerization studies it became evident that the ethers of bivinyl would not polymerize under the action of free-radical catalysts This led to an investigation of the polar polymerization and the allied problem of the effect of monomer polarity on the rate of polymerization. Also the optical properties of the unsaturated ethers suggested further that certain substituted dienes have unusual structural features which give rise to conjugation beyond that usually recognized. It was, therefore decided to investigate the more fundamental problem of conjugation and its effect on the polar polymerization reactions of some substituted butadienes.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The estimation and location of the carbonyl groups in chromium-trioxide oxy-starch
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The major part of this thesis is concerned with the preparation and analysis of chromium trioxide oxy-starch, oxy-amylose and oxy-amylopectin. The latter part of the thesis describes a fairly successful attempt to locate the positions of some of the carbonyl groups in the oxystarch by an application of the Kiliani synthesis.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A survey of the role of nutrition in sterility of dairy cattle
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Nutrition, then, seems to have a general role in the development and functioning of the reproductive organs; however, as recent discoveries have indicated that various nutrients have specific functions in reproductive processes nutrition must play a very significant role in many reproductive phenomena.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nutrition

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Faulting in the St. Lawrence plain
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: No complete correlation of the structure over the whole area had yet been attempted in the light of the newer data, and at the suggestion of Dr. F. F/ Osborne of the Department of Geological Sciences at McGlll University, the author undertook the present study. The intention is to show the influence of the faults in determining the present shape of the plain, and to indicate if possible, whether the fault pattern is concordant throughout, whether more than one period of faulting may be present and what relations the faults may hold to the different orogenic and epeiorogenic movements which have affected the eastern part of North America since early Paleozoic times. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Science

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some factors affecting the capacity and efficiency of a spray drying unit
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The present writer has obtained some data on the performance under certain conditions of an experimental, pilot scale dryer, designed by the writer for t h i s purpose and constructed and erected in the Chemical Engineering Laboratory of McGill University. The general requirements for a dryer will be discussed in Chapter II, the constructional, operational and control details in Chapter III, the theoretical considerations i n Chapter IV, the experimental results will be given in Chapter V and a discussion will be presented in Chapter VI. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Etude des m√©thodes pr√©conis√©es pour l‚Äôenseignement du fran√ßais comme langue √©trang√®re de 1850 √† 1944
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Cette these est une etude documentaire et critique des methodes qui furent preconisees pour l'enseignement du franqais en tant que langue etrangere de 1850 a 1944. Notre travail se propose un triple hut: 1) exposer les principales methodes qui furent e1aborees au cours de ces annees, tout en notant ce qui, & notre avis, fait leur valeur et leur faiblesse; 2) indiquer ce que chacune de ces methodes a apporte en fait de progres reel a la methodologie de l'enseignement des langues vivantes; 3) faire ressortir, enfin, les principes pedagogiques qui, selon nous, reposent sur les plus solides arguments et qui sont admis du plus grand nombre des methodologistes. II est bon de noter que dans cette these il s'agit surtout de l'enseignement du francais aux debutants.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French
FRENCH LANGUAGE -- STUDY AND TEACHING

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Methods for the induction of epileptiform abnormality in the electroencephalogram of epileptic patients
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The plan of the study was to test the effect of various agents upon well-defined types of electroencephalographic abnormality; and when a satisfactory method for increasing known abnormality was found, to utilize the agent for the induction of epileptic discharge in epileptics with normal records. It was hoped that the electrographic abnormality induced would represent the latent pattern of the individual patient. Control records in non-epileptic individuals if negative would add further importance to the significance of a negative electroencephalogram in a non-epileptic functional disturbance. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The odontoblast method of bioassay versus chemical methods of assaying vitamin C.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Results of all vitamin C bioassays by the odontoblast method completed to date in this laboratory were reviewed and discussed. The odontoblast method of bioassay was compared with two chemical methods of assay, the indophenol method of Hochberg, Melnick and Oser and the phenylhydrazine method of Roe and Gesterling. The ascorbic acid potencies of nine vitamin C carriers, assayed biologically in this laboratory and chemically in the Department of Chemistry, served as a basis for this comparison. These assay materials included six fortified juices, freshly opened, and opened and stored apple juices, tomato juice, and three canned orange juices fortified in varying proportions; and three unfortified juices, high and low potency tomato juices and canned orange juice. Statistical analysis of the chemical and biological potencies of fortified and unfortified juices indicated that chemical methods underestimated the biological potencies of the fortified juices. The two chemical methods agreed closely in the estimation of vitamin C potencies of all juices, and satisfactorily estimated the biological potencies of unfortified juices.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nutrition

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A survey of the conflicts in Donne‚Äôs life and thought which contributed to metaphysical wit
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In spite of many opposed and conflicting opinions concerning Donne, much remains unexplained in his personality and his work. Opinions have very seldom been temperate, but have varied in extreme degree according to the bias and interest of the critic. At one pole we have the hero-worship of Isaac Walton, at the other, the condemnation of Sidney Dark who brands Donne thus: [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Geology and petrology of the anorthosite and associated rocks of the Chertsey map-area
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The area covers the eastern portion of the Morin anorthosite massif north of Montreal. The mapped geological units include a zone of coarse anorthosite of the "Ashton facies", a quite broad zone of sheared anorthosite of the "Chertsey facies", concordant bodies of sheared quartz mangerite, and an elongated boss of unsheared alaskite; rocks of the Grenville series bound the massif on its eastern side and form several 'inclusions' within the anorthosite and the mangerite. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geological Sciences

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the utilization of open-hearth slag as a fertilizer
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The investigation described In this thesis was part of an intensive research program commenced in 1942 through the establishment of the Nova Scotia Agricultural and Metallurgical Slag Committees (more generally knovm as the Slag Committee) by the Honourable J. A. MacDonald, then Minister of Agriculture for Nova Scotia. The Slag Committee, made up of representatives of the Nova Scotia Department of Agriculture and Marketing, Dominion Department of Agriculture, National Research Council of Canada, Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, Nova Scotia Department of Mines, and the Nova Scotia Technical College, was directed to make a thorough investigation into the pos3ibility of utilizing In agriculture, the basic open-hearth slags produced at Sydney, Nova Scotia. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The use of the photodisintegration of deuterium in a cloud chamber in the determination of the energy of the hard gamma ray from lanthanum 140
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A method by means of which the energy of energetic gamma rays may be measured with a cloud Chamber is described. In this method, the Chamber is filled with deuterium gas and the gamma rays to be measured are allowed to pass through the Chamber. The lengths of the proton tracks resulting from the photodisintegration of the deuterium are measured. From the lengths of these tracks, the energy of the protons can be found by means of the r√§nge energy relation. From this energy, and the fact that the neutron resulting from the photodisintegration will have the same energy, and the known binding energy of the deuteron, the energy of the incident gamma ray can be calculated.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Introduction to the generalized theory of multi-system macroeconomics
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis is largely original. The first chapter was inspired by a desire to improve upon Ragnar Frisch's equation for the principle of acceleration. This inspiration was found in a paragraph in Bretherton, Burchardt & Rutherford's Public Investment and the Trade Cycle, on pp. 319-20. Prof. Tinbergen's article, An Acceleration Principle for Stocks, also influenced Chapter 1, although the substance of the chapter had been conceived before I read it.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics
POLITICAL ECONOMY
